{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3424440,"name":"sam liu","username":"catrix","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/dbc845/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-09-17T14:17:57.884Z","cooked":"

Demo Videos

What is this?

As mentioned in the title, you can play this project like a driving simulator game. However, unlike other driving simulators like MoSimulator, which are built on game engines, this “game” is actually a simulation of the Java robot code running on our physical off-season robot, “11:59.” This same robot competed in the 2024 Beijing WRC Off-Season Event.

cgi-bin_mmwebwx-bin_webwxgetmsgimg_&MsgID=128748877247322637&skey=@crypt_e23f8ed8_b4eda57d82ee47e566b68aecc1d17c72&mmweb_appid=wx_webfilehelper1280×2275 195 KB

In this simulator, everything that happens to your robot in real life also happens in the virtual environment:

  • The mechanisms are simulated using WPILib Physics Simulation.
  • The auto-aim feature is powered by a vision system, simulated through PhotonLib Simulation.
  • The chassis is modeled mathematically, calculating the motors’ propelling forces and the wheels’ gripping forces for a realistic driving experience.

Additionally, AI robots can assist in practicing various strategies, such as feed-and-shoot drills, providing a versatile training experience.

Other Capabilities

In addition to driver practice, a realistic simulation is a valuable tool for programmers. It allows you to fine-tune your code or adjust autonomous stages without needing the physical robot, making development and testing more efficient.

During the build season, this means you can begin writing robot code as soon as the robot’s design is finalized. By the time the robot is fully built, you’ll already have a well-tested robot code in the simulator, and you might even have a conceptual autonomous stage ready to go.

Playing this demo

github.com

Maple-Swerve-Skeleton/example/5516-2024-OffSeason at main ·...

Iron Maple's swerve-drive skeleton project, based on 6328's Advanced Swerve Drive Example - Shenzhen-Robotics-Alliance/Maple-Swerve-Skeleton

If you are not used to FRC Java programming, you might need some help from a programmer in your team

  1. Open the latest build of Advantage-Scope, select Help -> Use Custom Assets Folder, select Maple-Swerve-Skelton/example/5516-2024-OffSeason/AdvantageScopeAssets
  2. In WPILib Vscode, run Simulate Java according to this guide
  3. In Advantage Scope:
    • Drag AdvantageKit/RealOutputs/Field/Robot to 2D Poses, make it Robot
    • Drag AdvantageKit/RealOutputs/Field/Note to 3D Poses, make it Note
    • Drag AdvantageKit/RealOutputs/Shooter/MechanismPose to 3D Poses, make it Component (Robot)
    • Drag AdvantageKit/RealOutputs/Field/RobotBlue to 3D Poses, make it Blue Ghost (these are blue AI robots)
    • Drag AdvantageKit/RealOutputs/Field/RobotRed to 3D Poses, make it Red Ghost (these are red AI-robots)
  4. Double-Right-Click the 3D field, Select DriverStation -> and choose a driver-station view
  5. Attach an Xbox Game Controller to Simulation GUI
  6. in the Simulation GUI, select Teleoperated to begin Teleop simulation
  7. You can also select autonomous mode in SmartDashboard/SelectAuto in your dashboard, select Autonomous in the simulation GUI. If you want the robot to also shoot preload, grab a note in Teleoperated mode, select Disable mode and then select Autonomous mode.

Creating Realistic Simulations For Your Own Robot

This project is generated using Maple Swerve Skeleton. If you use this skeleton to create your own robot code, the simulator will perfectly match your real robot. Key elements like mass, gearing, motors, and program logic will all be identical, making it ideal for driver practice early in the build season.

github.com

GitHub - Shenzhen-Robotics-Alliance/Maple-Swerve-Skeleton: Iron Maple's swerve-drive skeleton project, based...

Iron Maple's swerve-drive skeleton project, based on 6328's Advanced Swerve Drive Example

Setup Guide

Sokoloff","username":"sokoloff","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/sokoloff/{size}/231724_2.png","created_at":"2024-10-06T12:42:24.051Z","cooked":"

This demo looks really slick and I’m trying to “bring it up” on my own PC here, using the example/demo code first before tackling our own robot.

I got the basics working, I can drive the robot in the 2D (“Odometry”) pane; I can see the notes and opponent/alliance robots in the 3D Field, but I don’t have the following anywhere in the NT outputs to visualize “my” robot in the 3D field.

If I poke around the Network Table Real Outputs, I don’t see anything that looks like a 3D pose for the player robot.

catrix:

Drag AdvantageKit/RealOutputs/Shooter/MechanismPose to 3D Poses, make it Component (Robot)

I’m using

Advantage Scope Version: 4.0.0-beta-1
commit 64b5addffb74259716e2930b8efe7c5f99eaf6a2 (HEAD -> main, origin/main, origin/HEAD)

I also tried a couple of older commits and didn’t get anywhere, but that could be that I was just repeating whatever mistake was causing my original issue.

Iron Maple Sim Attempt 011165×1240 193 KB

Any tips would be greatly appreciated!

I think I fixed at least half of my issue. I had to drag the Robot 2D pose onto the 3D field and set it to a robot. That lets me drive around a robot at least, though I still don’t have the 3D Shooter mechanism (but that doesn’t block me from doing what I want to do this week).

BTW: This is absolutely incredible.

Certainly! You need to import the robot model asset.

catrix:

Open the latest build of Advantage-Scope , select Help -> Use Custom Assets Folder, select Maple-Swerve-Skelton/example/5516-2024-OffSeason/AdvantageScopeAssets

And that error should disapear.

No problem at all, happy to help!

The ‘swerve skeleton’ is our core swerve drive code. The physics sim stuff started out built directly into the skeleton as utility classes.

We later created ‘MapleSim’ as a general library to make the physics simulation easily usable by anyone, no matter what code base they use.
